18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Christmas 1925 at home. And at my own place 1929. Great food at home. Festive, joyful times. Laughter and love all around. First, just the above mentioned family. I don't remember the housekeeper's name.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

After 1907 when the potato crop was very poor and the prairie was covered with snow. We had to rely on the local grocer for most of our food. Muffins and bread were made by hand. The coffee was ground in the mill and used for tea. We were forced to live on a diet of flour and water. We borrowed a cook stove from a neighbor and it had been used to make tea over an open fire. It was a tough time.

The storage of many foodstuffs was a problem. Father bought a table of proper proportions and placed our flour or rice in a cool place to keep it from getting too hot. We also stored our vegetables in the basement, much more convenient than upstairs. We had the experience that when we moved into the house, we cut up firewood piled up or raised upstairs and stacked it inside a closet or opening where it could not be seen. But after a while, we found that it was quite warm there and could get quite hot. So we moved it to another place where it was cooler.

We also had a cellar under the living room floor, which was used for some household items and meat.
The storage of many goods also has a problem. If there's a lack of proper food and heat in the building or it's too cold, much more expensive storage space is needed. For example, we have the opportunity to store firewood in a room that already has a fireplace. This can be used as an additional source of heat when it's cold outside. We could also use an attic or cellar as storage space for meat and other supplies. However, there are no facilities for these purposes.

The living quarters require two or three floors for some households. Some amish people
